quoteFirst: It appears to have been on a Sunday, and when his friends came, as they were accustomed to do, on the Sunday evening to supper--and they seem to have mustered strongly on this particular evening--he was able to receive them with something of his usual cheerfulness. He would even have stayed up and sat with them had they allowed him, but they pressed him not to do so, and he retired to bed about
quoteLast: . As he left the room he turned and said, "I love your company, gentlemen, but I believe I must leave you to go to another world." These are the words as reported by Henry Mackenzie, who was present, in giving Samuel Rogers an account of Smith's death during a visit he paid to London in the course of the following year.
title: Life of Adam Smith
author: Rae, John, 1845-1915

quoteFirst: Then he turned to a person behind him, and said, “You hear, M. Noir, the hour is altered to
quoteLast: .” Whereupon M. Noir bowed, expressed his thanks, and went away. My accomplice continued:

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: the half-breed returned to head-quarters with the intelligence that all the chiefs and warriors were saddling up to leave, under circumstances showing that they had no intention of returning, such as packing up every article that could be carried with them, and cutting and destroying their lodges--this last being done to obtain small pieces for temporary shelter.
title: The Old Santa Fe Trail: The Story of a Great Highway
author: Inman, Henry, 1837-1899; Buffalo Bill, 1846-1917 [Commentator]

quoteFirst: Lincoln's terms. Thus, at
quoteLast: on the night of February 1, their mission was practically at an end, though next day they again recanted and accepted the President's conditions in writing. title:

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: by the meet'n'-house clock,-- Just the hour of the Earthquake shock! What do you think the parson found, When he got up and stared around? The poor old chaise in a heap or mound, As if it had been to the mill and ground! You see, of course, if you're not a dunce, How it went to pieces all at once,-- All at once and nothing first,--
title:
The Funny Side of Physic

quoteLast: till twelve. The Captain and Wilkes had taken the other watches by turns.
title: When London Burned : a Story of Restoration Times and the Great Fire
author: Henty, G. A. (George Alfred), 1832-1902

quoteFirst: The farmers, the fruit-raisers, the growers of grapes and all the birds and beasts of the field had been begging for rain for weeks. No doubt they rejoiced in the steady downpour that came at
quoteLast: , but what must have been their joy at ten when the very floodgates of heaven opened wide and let loose all the dammed waters of July and August (and perhaps some that was being saved up for the approaching September!) I have never known it to rain so hard as it did on that Thursday night in August, nor have I ever ceased reviling the fate that instituted, on the very next day, a second season of drought that lasted for nearly six weeks.
title: A Fool and His Money
author: McCutcheon, George Barr, 1866-1928

quoteFirst: And the second thing which kept her going was to see the evidences of prosperity and contentment which the women on the payroll began to show--their new clothes and shoes--the hopeful confidence of their smiles--the frequency with which the furniture dealers' wagons were seen in the streets around the factory, the sounds of pianos and phonographs in the evening and, better than all, the fact that on pay day at Spencer & Sons, the New Bethel Savings Bank stayed open till
quoteLast: at night--and didn't stay open for nothing!
title: Mary Minds Her Business
author: Weston, George, 1880-1965

quoteFirst: came to see me, and I did not go to bed till half-past seven. But I had to be waked out of my first sleep, for at
quoteLast: the carriers brought the "Adam and Eve" and the "Saint Peter," and my presence was necessary. The concierge had paid sixty francs too much, and I had to explain the error.

quoteFirst: He might have returned to his trench in safety; but he preferred to remain with a comrade who had been stricken down and was unable to move. For forty-eight hours he lay by his friend, and then fixed a shovel to the man's equipment, and, using it as a sledge, dragged the poor fellow back over 600 yards to his own lines, which he reached about
quoteLast: on the evening of 23rd August.

The Children's Story of the War Volume 4 (of 10)

quoteLast: , half an hour before the market opens, the weighmen, all garbed in immaculate white, meet in executive session in the weigh-house and absorb a ceremonious talking-to by the superintendent of the market--probably upon the subject of honest weights and the penalties to be imposed upon the unfortunate man caught trifling with the rules and regulations of the game.
title: Windmills and Wooden Shoes

quoteFirst: At length the clock on the mantelpiece warned us that it was already
quoteLast: , and that we had been three hours at dinner. It was clearly time to vary the evening's amusement in some way or other, and the only question was what next to do? Should we go to a billiard-room? Or to the Salle Valentinois? Or to some of the cheap theatres on the Boulevard du Temple? Or to the Tableaux Vivants? Or the Café des Aveugles? Or take a drive round by the Champs Elysées in an open fly?
title: In the Days of My Youth: A Novel
author: Edwards, Amelia B., 1831-1892
